interventions.original_text: pure essential oils of lavender, bergamot, and cedarwood administered by inhalation

metadata.purpose: to determine whether the inhalation of aromatherapy during radiotherapy reduces anxiety.
metadata.conclusion: aromatherapy, as administered in this study, is not beneficial.

metadata.purpose: to investigate the extraction of cedarwood oil using liquid carbon dioxide and compare it to supercritical fluid extraction.
metadata.conclusion: the extraction rate of cedarwood oil was highest under supercritical extraction conditions, and the chemical composition varied with temperature and pressure, affecting the cedrol/cedrene ratio.

metadata.purpose: to explore the synthesis and sensory aspects of new molecules derived from cedarwood and turpentine oil for fragrance applications.
metadata.conclusion: the study highlights the potential of using renewable resources like cedarwood oil to synthesize new molecules with excellent olfactory properties, such as ambrocenide, which can be developed from alpha-cedrene.

metadata.purpose: to identify odor-active compounds in the spicy fraction of hop essential oil from four different varieties.
metadata.conclusion: an intense 'woody, cedarwood' odor was determined to be the most potent odorant in three of the four spicy fraction samples, tentatively identified as 14-hydroxy-beta-caryophyllene.

metadata.purpose: to summarize the talk at the rsc/sci conference 'flavours & fragrances 2007' and present new experimental results on woody odorants.
metadata.conclusion: the study presents new insights into the structure-odor correlation of spirocyclic hydroxy ketone analogs and highlights stereochemical requirements for woody odorants.

metadata.purpose: to study the antibacterial activity of nine commercially available essential oils against streptococcus mutans in vitro and to compare the antibacterial activity between each material.
metadata.conclusion: cinnamon oil showed highest activity against streptococcus mutans followed by lemongrass oil and cedarwood oil. the use of these essential oils against s. mutans can be a viable alternative to other antibacterial agents.

metadata.population: third instars of cecidomyiid gall midge camptomyia corticalis
metadata.purpose: to examine the toxicity of 98 plant essential oils against third instars of cecidomyiid gall midge camptomyia corticalis using a vapor-phase mortality bioassay.
metadata.conclusion: all essential oils were less toxic than dichlorvos, with virginian cedarwood oil having an lc50 between 0.61 and 0.99 mg/cm3, indicating potential as a larvicide for c. corticalis control.

metadata.purpose: to describe the use of cedarwood oil as a complementary treatment in refractory acne.
metadata.conclusion: the addition of cedarwood oil was helpful in controlling acne in a patient with refractory acne.

metadata.population: studies on the repellency effects of plants against anopheles mosquitoes
metadata.purpose: to assess the effectiveness of plant-based repellents against anopheles mosquitoes
metadata.conclusion: essential oils and extracts of some plants, including cedarwood, showed good repellency with 8 hours complete repellency against different species of anopheles.

metadata.purpose: to investigate the inter-specific variability effect on the biological activities of each oil.
metadata.conclusion: the tested oils possessed good antibacterial activities against e.coli and s. aureus justifying its folk use as a topical antiseptic while the observed anti-inflammatory effects in human wbcs is due at least in part to their inhibitory effect on the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

metadata.population: patients with inflammatory skin conditions such as acne vulgaris, dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis, and rosacea
metadata.purpose: to generate a broad overview of the essential oils used to treat inflammatory skin conditions in a clinical setting
metadata.conclusion: the uncontrolled studies indicated the potential efficacy of cedarwood (cedrus libani) oil in the treatment of acne, but further research is required to reach conclusive evidence.

interventions.original_text: massaged essential oils (thyme, rosemary, lavender, and cedarwood) in a mixture of carrier oils (jojoba and grapeseed) into their scalp daily

metadata.purpose: to investigate the efficacy of aromatherapy in the treatment of patients with alopecia areata.
metadata.conclusion: the results show aromatherapy to be a safe and effective treatment for alopecia areata. treatment with these essential oils was significantly more effective than treatment with the carrier oil alone (p = .008 for the primary outcome measure).

metadata.purpose: to search for xanthine oxidase inhibitors in natural products obtained from plants collected in puerto rico and to assess the influence of these extracts in the prevention of cataractogenesis.
metadata.conclusion: eucalyptus deglupta presented the best finding for cataractogenesis prevention, while syzygium malaccense demonstrated the greatest xanthine oxidase inhibitory activity.

metadata.population: wood samples from two eucalyptus species of various ages and colors
metadata.purpose: to examine the feasibility of using fourier transform raman spectroscopy for rapid determination of proportion of cell types in native wood.
metadata.conclusion: fourier transform raman spectroscopy, combined with second derivative transformation and partial least-squares regression, provides highly significant correlations with microscopically measured values for determining cell type proportions in eucalyptus wood.

metadata.population: children with acute maxillary sinusitis, exacerbation of chronic purulent maxillary sinusitis and peritonsillar abscess
metadata.purpose: to evaluate the antiinflammatory effect of eucalymine in children with acute inflammatory ent diseases
metadata.conclusion: eucalymine shows a good antiinflammatory effect and can be used as a treatment of choice in children with ent diseases.

metadata.purpose: to measure the penetration of solar erythemal ultraviolet radiation in the shade of a gum (eucalyptus sp.) and a she oak (casaurina) tree.
metadata.conclusion: the denser foliage of the she oak provided higher ultraviolet protection compared to that of the gum tree.

metadata.purpose: to update on human defenses against cryptococcus neoformans, focusing on immune responses and susceptibility in aids patients.
metadata.conclusion: susceptibility of aids patients to cryptococcus neoformans is associated with low cd4+ t cell counts and likely reduced efficacy of the second line of defense.

metadata.purpose: to compare the antibacterial activity of australian tea tree oil with various other essential myrtaceous oils including eucalyptus oil.
metadata.conclusion: eucalyptus oil was tested for antibacterial activity against various bacteria using a broth microdilution method, but pseudomonas aeruginosa was resistant to all essential oils tested, even at the highest concentration of 4%.

interventions.original_text: absorption of several of these oils for therapeutic purposes

metadata.purpose: to report cases of seizures related to the absorption of plant-derived essential oils, including eucalyptus, for therapeutic purposes.
metadata.conclusion: the study reports three cases of seizures related to the absorption of plant-derived essential oils, including eucalyptus, highlighting the potential for these oils to cause toxic seizures.

metadata.population: eucalyptus pilularis and pisolithus tinctorius ectomycorrhizas
metadata.purpose: to analyze the distribution of polyphosphate in fungal vacuoles of ectomycorrhizas between pisolithus tinctorius and eucalyptus pilularis.
metadata.conclusion: polyphosphate is present in the vacuoles of the fungal cells of these ectomycorrhizas in a dispersed form, not in granules.

metadata.population: patients with superficial fungal infections diagnosed as tinea pedis, tinea corporis, or tinea cruris
metadata.purpose: to investigate the antifungal activity of eucalyptus pauciflora oil against superficial fungal infections
metadata.conclusion: the eucalyptus pauciflora oil showed strong antifungal activity in vitro and was effective in treating superficial fungal infections in patients, with 60% recovering completely and 40% showing significant improvement.

interventions.original_text: a diet containing a mixture of terpenes found in eucalyptus leaves

metadata.purpose: to study the induction of xenobiotic metabolising enzymes in the common brushtail possum by eucalyptus terpenes.
metadata.conclusion: dietary terpenes cause enzyme induction in folivorous marsupials, confirming the importance of diet knowledge when studying xenobiotic metabolising enzymes in wild animals like the brushtail possum.

interventions.original_text: 125 ml of a 20 per cent eucalyptus compositum solution

metadata.purpose: to compare three management programmes for improving reproductive performance in a dairy herd with endometritis.
metadata.conclusion: management programmes based on the strategic use of PGF2alpha are an effective alternative to traditional programmes based on rectal palpations and intrauterine infusions to control endometritis at a herd level.

metadata.purpose: to study the influence of various extraction parameters on the yield and qualitative composition of lipids extracted from eucalyptus globulus wood using supercritical carbon dioxide modified with methanol.
metadata.conclusion: the qualitative and quantitative results obtained by supercritical carbon dioxide extraction and soxhlet extraction with acetone were in good agreement.

metadata.population: patients with dermatological conditions using herbal treatments
metadata.purpose: to address the adverse effects of herbal drugs in dermatology in a semisystematic fashion
metadata.conclusion: adverse effects of herbal medicines are an important albeit neglected subject in dermatology, which deserves further systematic investigation.

metadata.population: humans and warm-blooded animals with cryptococcosis
metadata.purpose: to investigate the etiological agents of cryptococcosis and their environmental sources
metadata.conclusion: cryptococcus neoformans, particularly variety gattii, is associated with eucalyptus trees and causes cryptococcosis in humans and animals, with a geographical distribution in tropical and subtropical regions.

metadata.population: eucalyptus grandis hill ex maiden stand in brazil
metadata.purpose: to compare the efficiency of different trap types for ambrosia beetles in eucalyptus stands in brazil.
metadata.conclusion: the esalq-84 trap was the most efficient in trapping hypothenemus eruditus and hypothenemus obscurus, while the slot trap caught more of the three most economically important scolytid species in eucalypt plantations in brazil.

metadata.purpose: to highlight the global cultivation and uses of eucalyptus, including timber, fuel, essential oil, and cut foliage.
metadata.conclusion: eucalyptus is a widely cultivated tree, covering ten million hectares worldwide, and is valued for its timber, fuel, essential oil, and cut foliage.

metadata.purpose: to investigate tolbutamide hydroxylase as a probe substrate reaction in koala and brushtail possum liver microsomes and examine inhibition by eucalyptus terpenes.
metadata.conclusion: 1,8-cineole was found to be a competitive inhibitor for the enzyme responsible for tolbutamide hydroxylation in the possum, while in koala liver microsomes, stimulation of tolbutamide hydroxylase activity was observed with increased cineole concentrations.

metadata.population: koalas (phascolarctos cinereus) including 5 pouched young and 10 adults
metadata.purpose: to analyze the anatomy and development of koalas from an evolutionary perspective on the superfamily vombatoidea.
metadata.conclusion: musculoskeletal structures correlated with sitting and climbing; the growth of the young and the physiological demands of adulthood correlated with the low-quality diet of eucalyptus foliage.

metadata.purpose: to compare two instruments for measuring rates of leaf decay using biological oxygen demand.
metadata.conclusion: decay measurements obtained by both instruments were nearly identical for casuarina cunninghamiana and eucalyptus polyanthemos, indicating the feasibility of using both instruments for comparable measurements of leaf decay rates.

metadata.purpose: to compare the major components of eucalyptus camaldulensis oils obtained by hydrodistillation and supercritical carbon dioxide extraction.
metadata.conclusion: the oil obtained by hydrodistillation showed high concentrations of 1,8-cineole, alpha-pinene, beta-pinene, p-cymene, terpinen-4-ol, and globulol, while supercritical carbon dioxide extraction resulted in lower amounts of these components but higher amounts of allo-aromadendrene and globulol.

synergies_interactions_negative: 1,8-cineole inhibited 1,4-cineole 2-hydroxylation catalysed by human liver microsomes
metadata.purpose: to study the oxidation of 1,4-cineole by rat and human liver microsomes and recombinant cytochrome p450 enzymes.
metadata.conclusion: 1,4-cineole and 1,8-cineole are converted to 2-hydroxylated products by cyp3a enzymes in rat and human liver microsomes.

metadata.population: energy crops including salix viminalis and eucalyptus nitens
metadata.purpose: to investigate the spatial root distribution of energy crops in response to dairy farm pond effluent irrigation.
metadata.conclusion: spatial root distribution was influenced by effluent rate, with greater quantities of both fine and coarse roots in the top soil horizons with the higher effluent rate of 300 m3 ha(-1) compared to 150 m3 ha(-1).

metadata.purpose: to compare the raman spectra of dragon's blood resins from different botanical sources and identify key vibrational spectroscopic marker bands for identification purposes.
metadata.conclusion: key vibrational spectroscopic marker bands are identified in the raman spectra of the resins, which are suggested for adoption as a protocol for the identification of the botanical and possible geographical sources of modern dragon's blood resins.

metadata.purpose: to determine the required hlb values of eucalyptus, lippia, and peppermint essential oils using droplet size analysis and turbidimetric method.
metadata.conclusion: the required hlb values of eucalyptus, lippia, and peppermint oils were determined as 9.8, 12.1, and 12.3, respectively, using droplet size analysis and turbidimetric method.

metadata.purpose: to examine the metabolism of p-cymene by liver microsomes from the possum, koala, and rat.
metadata.conclusion: animals adapted to a diet of eucalyptus leaf have a greater capacity to metabolize dietary terpenes than generalist feeders.

metadata.population: standardized samples of root canal sealers

interventions.original_text: immersed in chloroform or eucalyptus oil for 30 seconds, 1 minute, 2 minutes, 5 minutes, 10 minutes, and 20 minutes

metadata.purpose: to compare the solubility of different root canal sealers in chloroform and eucalyptus oil
metadata.conclusion: under the conditions of this study, chloroform was a far more effective solvent of root canal sealers than eucalyptus oil.

metadata.population: human participants in vaca diez province, bolivian amazon
metadata.purpose: to evaluate the efficacy of three plant-based insect repellents against malaria vectors in bolivia.
metadata.conclusion: the eucalyptus-based repellent containing 30% p-menthane-diol provided 96.89% protection against anopheles darlingi for 4 hours, outperforming 15% deet which provided 84.81% protection.

metadata.purpose: to understand the dynamics of cryptococcus neoformans var. gattii in australian environments using koalas as natural biological samplers.
metadata.conclusion: a strong association between healthy koalas and cryptococcus neoformans var. gattii was confirmed, and the organism was isolated from novel sources, including eucalyptus microcorys and e. grandis.

interventions.original_text: natural oil formulations (containing citronella, clover, eucalyptus, geranium, lavender, peppermint, sandalwood, thyme, etc.)

metadata.purpose: to compare the repellent activity of natural oil formulations and a synthetic chemical repellent against aedes aegypti.
metadata.conclusion: natural oil products, including those containing eucalyptus, showed poor or no repellency against aedes aegypti, with protection times less than or equal to 1 hour. only the synthetic repellent based on kbr 3023 provided satisfactory defense to human volunteers.

metadata.population: eucalyptus short rotation forest species irrigated with meatworks effluent compared with no irrigation
metadata.purpose: to measure biomass and nutrient accumulation in eucalyptus short rotation energy forests in new zealand
metadata.conclusion: eucalyptus globulus had the highest biomass and nutrient accumulation, with effluent irrigation increasing the accumulation of biomass, n, p, k, and mn, but reducing the leaf area index and leaf biomass, and decreasing the accumulation of ca and mg.

metadata.purpose: to demonstrate that the vascular expression pattern conferred by the eucalyptus gunnii egcad2 promoter is conserved among woody and herbaceous plant species.
metadata.conclusion: the mechanisms controlling developmental and wounding inducible expression of the egcad2 promoter are conserved among perennial woody and annual herbaceous plant species.

metadata.population: common ringtail (pseudocheirus peregrinus) and common brushtail possums (trichosurus vulpecula)
metadata.purpose: to study the effect of tannins and formylated phloroglucinol compounds on the intake of eucalyptus foliage by common ringtail and common brushtail possums.
metadata.conclusion: brushtail possums showed greater tolerance to formylated phloroglucinol compounds and ate more foliage when coated with polyethylene glycol, while ringtail possums were tolerant of tannins but susceptible to low concentrations of formylated phloroglucinol compounds.

metadata.purpose: to evaluate the anti-inflammatory efficacy of 1.8-cineol by determining its prednisolone equivalent potency in patients with severe asthma.
metadata.conclusion: long-term systemic therapy with 1.8-cineol has a significant steroid-saving effect in steroid-dependent asthma, suggesting an anti-inflammatory activity of the monoterpene 1.8-cineol in asthma.

metadata.population: mosquitoes consisting mainly of mansonia in gambella, western ethiopia
metadata.purpose: to evaluate the repellent activity of essential oils of lemon eucalyptus and other plant products against mosquito populations in western ethiopia
metadata.conclusion: the essential oil of lemon eucalyptus showed significant repellent activity at 40% and 75% concentrations, with better performance at 75% compared to pyrethrum and neem.
